The morning mist clung to the cobblestone streets of Inverurie like a reluctant ghost, swirling around the ankles of early commuters who hurried past the unassuming shop nestled between MacLeod's bakery and the old pharmacy. Above the narrow doorway, a weathered sign creaked in the Highland breeze, its faded letters spelling out "Mystic Remedies & Curiosities." Most passersby assumed it sold herbal teas and crystal trinkets to tourists, which suited Hamish MacBride perfectly.

Behind the dusty window display of allegedly magical stones and dried herbs, Hamish was having what could charitably be called a morning crisis. The source of his distress strutted boldly across the small courtyard behind his shop—a magnificent red cockerel that belonged to Mrs. Aberdeen next door. The bird's proud chest puffed out as it surveyed its domain, completely unaware that it was causing a fully qualified wizard to cower behind his kitchen curtains.

"Blasted creature," Hamish muttered, his Scottish accent thick with irritation and embarrassment. At forty-three, he possessed considerable magical abilities that had taken decades to master, yet the sight of any cockerel reduced him to a quivering mess. The phobia had plagued him since childhood, when his grandmother's prize rooster had chased him up a tree and left him stranded there for hours. Even now, the memory of those beady eyes and that razor-sharp beak made his hands shake.

The cockerel let out a piercing crow, and Hamish actually jumped backward, knocking over a precariously balanced stack of ancient grimoires. As he scrambled to collect the scattered books, his mobile phone buzzed with an incoming call. The display showed "Moira Sinclair," and he answered with relief at the distraction.

"Hamish, thank goodness you're there," came the breathless voice of his oldest friend and fellow practitioner. Moira ran a similar establishment in Edinburgh, though hers catered to a more upscale clientele. "I've got some rather disturbing news from the Magical Practices Council."

Hamish settled into his worn armchair, keeping one eye on the window in case the cockerel decided to venture closer. "What sort of disturbing news? Please tell me they haven't decided to audit my licensing again."

"Worse, I'm afraid. There've been reports of magical interference in the Highlands. Environmental disturbances that suggest someone's been practicing without proper regard for consequences." Moira's voice dropped to a whisper. "They think there's a rogue practitioner operating somewhere in your area."

The news should have concerned Hamish more than it did, but he was distracted by the sound of scratching at his back door. Through the glass panel, he could see the cockerel pecking at something on his doorstep. His mouth went dry, and he had to clear his throat before responding.

"What sort of environmental disturbances?" he managed, though his voice came out slightly higher than intended.

"That's the odd bit. The reports mention unusual accumulations of non-biodegradable materials appearing in natural settings. Specifically, plastic bags. Hundreds of them, just materializing in forests and glens where they have no business being." Moira paused, and he could hear papers rustling. "The council thinks someone might be using them as focus objects for spells, which is not only environmentally irresponsible but potentially dangerous."

Hamish frowned, momentarily forgetting about his feathered nemesis. Using plastic bags as magical focuses was indeed unusual. Most practitioners preferred natural materials—crystals, wood, metals—substances that had formed over time and held earth's energy. Plastic was synthetic, mass-produced, and generally considered unsuitable for serious magical work.

"That does sound peculiar," he admitted. "Have there been any other effects reported?"

"Oh yes, that's where it gets really worrying. Several hikers have reported getting lost on familiar trails, and there've been complaints about compasses spinning wildly in certain areas. Classic signs of magical interference with natural energy patterns." Moira's tone grew more serious. "The council wants all licensed practitioners in the region to keep their eyes open and report anything suspicious."

A sudden loud crash from outside made Hamish leap to his feet, his heart hammering. Through the window, he could see that Mrs. Aberdeen's cockerel had somehow managed to knock over his small garden table, scattering the herbs he'd been drying there. The bird stood triumphant among the wreckage, fixing Hamish with what seemed like a deliberately challenging stare.

"Hamish? Are you still there?"

"Yes, sorry. Just having a small... domestic situation." He turned away from the window, trying to ignore the continued sounds of destruction from his garden. "I'll certainly keep watch for anything unusual. Though to be honest, Moira, I don't venture out into the countryside as much as I probably should."

This was a considerable understatement. Hamish's fear of cockerels meant he avoided most rural areas, where the creatures roamed freely. His practice focused primarily on indoor work—potion brewing, charm creation, and consultations with clients who came to his shop. It was a limitation that embarrassed him professionally, though he'd never admitted the real reason to anyone.

"Well, perhaps this will give you good cause to expand your horizons," Moira said cheerfully. "The council is organizing a regional meeting next week in Huntly. All practitioners are expected to attend."

Hamish's stomach clenched. Huntly was surrounded by farms, which meant cockerels. Lots of them. "I'm not sure I can make it, Moira. I've got several important clients coming in next week, and—"

"Hamish MacBride, don't you dare think about missing this meeting. The council takes attendance very seriously, especially when there's a potential rogue practitioner in the area." Her voice softened slightly. "Besides, it'll do you good to get out of that shop and socialize with other practitioners. You've become quite the hermit."

After ending the call, Hamish slumped back in his chair and contemplated his predicament. The cockerel had finally wandered away from his garden, leaving behind a scene of considerable destruction. He'd have to venture outside eventually to clean up the mess, but for now, he was content to remain safely indoors.The shop's bell chimed softly as Hamish reluctantly made his way to the front, stepping carefully around the scattered grimoires he'd yet to properly reorganize. His first customer of the day stood examining a display of what appeared to be ordinary river stones, though each had been carefully selected for their natural magical properties. The woman was perhaps in her sixties, with silver hair pulled back in a practical bun and the weathered hands of someone who spent considerable time outdoors.

"Good morning," Hamish said, smoothing down his rumpled shirt and trying to project an air of professional competence despite his earlier encounter with Mrs. Aberdeen's cockerel. "I'm Hamish MacBride. Is there something particular you're looking for today?"

The woman turned, and he was struck by her unusually bright green eyes that seemed to assess him with uncomfortable intensity. She wore practical hiking boots and carried a well-used rucksack, suggesting she was indeed one of the tourists who occasionally wandered into his shop seeking Highland mysticism and locally-made trinkets.

"I'm hoping you might be able to help me with a rather unusual problem," she said, her accent marking her as English, probably from somewhere in the south. "I've been hiking in the area for the past week, and I've encountered some very strange occurrences that I'm told might require... specialized expertise."

Hamish felt a familiar flutter of anxiety in his chest. Clients seeking help with outdoor magical problems invariably expected him to venture into the countryside to investigate, which posed obvious difficulties given his phobia. He'd developed several polite ways to redirect such requests toward indoor consultations and remotely-prepared remedies, though he suspected his professional reputation suffered somewhat from his reluctance to do field work.

"I'd be happy to discuss whatever you've experienced," he said carefully, gesturing toward the small consultation area he'd arranged near the back of the shop. Two comfortable chairs faced each other across a low table where he typically laid out cards or examined objects clients brought for identification. "Perhaps you could start by describing what you've observed?"

The woman settled into the chair with obvious relief, setting her rucksack on the floor beside her. Up close, Hamish could see that despite her apparent fitness, she looked tired and somewhat shaken by whatever had brought her to his door. She reached into her jacket pocket and withdrew a crumpled plastic shopping bag, placing it on the table between them with the reverence usually reserved for dangerous artifacts.

"It started three days ago when I was walking the old drove road north of Alford," she began, her voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "I'd stopped for lunch in a lovely glen, completely pristine and remote, when I noticed something odd caught in the branches of a rowan tree. At first, I thought it was just litter blown in by the wind, but when I went to remove it, I found dozens more scattered throughout the area."

Hamish leaned forward, his interest genuinely piqued despite his growing concern about where this story might lead. The plastic bag on the table appeared ordinary enough—white with blue handles, the sort dispensed at any number of shops throughout Scotland. Yet something about it made his skin prickle with the familiar sensation that indicated magical residue.

"They weren't just randomly scattered, you see," the woman continued, watching his face carefully for his reaction. "They were arranged in patterns, almost like someone had deliberately placed them. And when I tried to collect them for proper disposal, the strangest thing happened. My compass began spinning wildly, and I became completely disoriented despite having walked that same path many times before."

The details matched perfectly with what Moira had told him about the reports reaching the Magical Practices Council. Hamish reached out tentatively toward the bag on the table, stopping just short of actually touching it. Even at a distance of several inches, he could feel the peculiar energy emanating from the seemingly mundane object. It wasn't the clean, natural power he was accustomed to working with, but something artificial and unsettling that made his magical senses recoil instinctively.

"Did you experience any other unusual effects?" he asked, pulling his hand back and folding his arms across his chest. "Changes in temperature, strange sounds, or perhaps the sensation of being watched?"

The woman nodded eagerly, clearly relieved to have found someone who took her account seriously rather than dismissing it as imagination or tourist nerves. "All of those things, actually. The area became unnaturally cold despite the sunny weather, and I kept hearing what sounded like whispering voices carried on the wind. But the most disturbing part was the feeling that something was deliberately trying to confuse me, to keep me wandering in circles."

Hamish's mind raced through the possibilities, none of them particularly pleasant. Magical practitioners occasionally used misdirection spells to protect sensitive locations or discourage unwanted visitors, but such workings typically employed natural focuses and were designed to guide people gently away rather than trap them in confusion. The use of plastic bags suggested someone with either very unconventional training or a deliberate disregard for proper magical principles.

"I managed to break free of whatever influence was affecting me," the woman continued, "but only after I'd been walking in circles for nearly three hours. When I finally found my way back to the main path, I looked back toward the glen and saw the most extraordinary sight. The plastic bags were moving despite there being no wind, fluttering and dancing as if they were alive."Hamish sat back in his chair, processing the woman's account with growing unease. The description of animated plastic bags defied several fundamental principles of magical practice that he'd learned during his formal training. Inanimate objects could certainly be enchanted to move or perform specific functions, but such spells required considerable skill and energy to maintain. More troubling was the apparent malevolent intent behind the working—deliberately disorienting hikers suggested someone using magic for harmful purposes, which violated the most basic ethical guidelines governing legitimate practitioners.

"I'm afraid what you've described sounds quite serious indeed," he said finally, trying to keep his voice steady despite the implications racing through his mind. "The good news is that you managed to escape whatever influence was affecting you, which suggests the magic involved isn't overwhelmingly powerful. The concerning part is that someone appears to be using enchanted objects to trap or confuse people in remote locations, which could pose genuine danger to other hikers."

The woman reached into her rucksack and withdrew a folded Ordnance Survey map, spreading it across the table with practiced efficiency. Her finger traced a route marked in red ink, following what Hamish recognized as one of the more remote hiking paths that wound through the hills north of his location. She'd marked several spots with small X's, and he noticed with growing alarm that they were scattered across a fairly wide area rather than concentrated in a single location.

"I've encountered these strange arrangements in three different locations over the past week," she explained, pointing to each marked spot in turn. "The first was near Corgarff Castle, the second along the Lecht Road, and the most recent in the glen I mentioned near Alford. Each time, the effect seemed stronger, as if whoever is responsible is either gaining confidence or increasing their magical output."

Hamish studied the map with growing dread, not because of the magical implications—though those were certainly serious enough—but because he recognized all three locations as areas where Mrs. Aberdeen's cockerel and its numerous countryside cousins would be roaming freely. The thought of venturing into such territory to investigate magical disturbances made his palms sweat and his heart rate accelerate in ways that had nothing to do with the potential dangers posed by rogue practitioners.

"Have you reported these incidents to the local authorities?" he asked, though he already suspected what the answer would be. The police were generally ill-equipped to handle magical disturbances, and most officers would likely dismiss such reports as the product of overactive imaginations or tourist unfamiliarity with Highland terrain.

The woman shook her head with obvious frustration. "I tried speaking to the constable in Huntly, but he seemed to think I'd simply gotten turned around due to inexperience, despite my explaining that I've been hiking these hills for over fifteen years. He did mention that there had been several other reports of hikers becoming lost in areas where they'd never had difficulty before, but he attributed it to unusually foggy weather patterns rather than anything supernatural."

This matched the pattern Moira had described, confirming that the situation was indeed serious enough to warrant the Magical Practices Council's attention. Hamish found himself in the uncomfortable position of being perhaps the only qualified practitioner in the immediate area who could investigate these incidents, while simultaneously being the least capable of actually doing so due to his debilitating phobia. The irony of his situation would have been amusing if it weren't so potentially dangerous for the hiking public.

"I think your instincts in seeking out specialized help were absolutely correct," he said, carefully refolding the map and handing it back to her. "What you've described definitely sounds like magical interference, and not the benign sort that legitimate practitioners might use to protect sensitive natural areas. The deliberate confusion and disorientation suggest someone with either malicious intent or a serious lack of understanding about the consequences of their actions."

The woman leaned forward intently, her green eyes brightening with what appeared to be relief at finally having her experiences taken seriously by someone with relevant expertise. "Does this mean you'll be able to help? I realize it might seem like a small matter compared to more dramatic magical emergencies, but I'm genuinely concerned about other hikers who might not be as fortunate as I was in finding their way out of those enchanted areas."

Hamish felt his throat tighten as he struggled to find a response that wouldn't reveal his shameful limitations while still offering some form of assistance. He could hardly explain that his fear of cockerels made fieldwork essentially impossible, nor could he simply refuse to help when someone's safety might be at stake. The professional reputation he'd spent years building would suffer considerably if word spread that he was unwilling to investigate legitimate magical disturbances in his own territory.

"I'll certainly need to look into this matter further," he said carefully, buying himself time to think of alternatives to personal field investigation. "However, I should mention that this situation may be part of a larger pattern that the regional magical authorities are already aware of. There's to be a meeting of practitioners next week where these incidents will undoubtedly be discussed and coordinated responses planned."

The mention of the upcoming meeting reminded him uncomfortably of his own reluctance to attend, and he realized that his professional obligations were rapidly becoming impossible to avoid. Whether he liked it or not, his expertise would be expected and required in dealing with whatever rogue practitioner was causing these disturbances. The thought of having to venture into cockerel-populated countryside while simultaneously tracking down potentially dangerous magical workings made him feel slightly nauseated.

"In the meantime," he continued, hoping his voice sounded more confident than he felt, "I'd strongly recommend that you avoid hiking alone in remote areas, particularly the locations you've already identified as problematic. If you do encounter any more unusual phenomena, please contact me immediately rather than trying to investigate further on your own."

The woman nodded seriously, gathering her belongings with the efficient movements of someone accustomed to outdoor adventures. She paused at the door, however, turning back with an expression that struck Hamish as oddly calculating for someone who had supposedly come seeking help with a frightening supernatural experience.

"I do hope you'll be able to resolve this situation quickly," she said, her tone carrying subtle undertones that made him suddenly uncomfortable. "It would be such a shame if these beautiful Highland paths became unsafe for visitors due to some practitioner's carelessness or malice. I'm sure someone with your obvious expertise will have no trouble tracking down whoever is responsible."

After she left, Hamish stood at his shop window watching her disappear down the cobblestone street with a growing sense that their conversation had contained layers of meaning he'd failed to fully grasp. Something about her manner in those final moments had shifted from grateful tourist to something more calculated and assessing, though he couldn't quite put his finger on what had triggered his unease. Perhaps it was simply his own guilt over his limitations coloring his perception of her perfectly reasonable expectations for professional assistance.**Chapter 2**

The afternoon brought an unseasonable chill that seemed to seep through the very stones of Inverurie, and Hamish found himself pacing restlessly around his shop while trying to make sense of the morning's unsettling encounter. The plastic bag the hiking woman had left behind sat on his consultation table like an accusation, its ordinary appearance belying the distinctly unnatural energy that continued to emanate from it in waves that made his skin crawl. Every few minutes, he would approach it with the intention of conducting a proper magical analysis, only to retreat again when the artificial wrongness of its aura became too overwhelming to bear. He had dealt with cursed objects before, items imbued with malevolent intent or corrupted by dark practices, but this felt different—not evil exactly, but fundamentally alien to the natural order of things in a way that defied his decades of experience.

The shop's bell chimed again just as he was contemplating whether to contact Moira for advice on handling the contaminated bag, and he looked up to see a familiar figure entering with the careful movements of someone trying not to disturb anything important. Dr. Margaret Sinclair—no relation to his Edinburgh colleague despite the shared surname—served as the local GP and had developed something of a reputation for referring patients with inexplicable ailments to Hamish's more unconventional practice. She was a practical woman in her fifties who had initially approached his services with considerable skepticism, only to become one of his most reliable sources of referrals after he'd successfully treated several cases that conventional medicine had failed to resolve.

"Good afternoon, Hamish," she said, settling her medical bag carefully beside one of his display cases filled with what appeared to tourists to be decorative crystals but were actually precisely calibrated healing stones. "I'm hoping you might have some insight into a rather puzzling situation that's developed over the past few days. I've had three separate patients present with symptoms that don't fit any conventional diagnosis, and they all share some rather unusual circumstances that I think might be relevant to your area of expertise."

Hamish felt a familiar sinking sensation in his stomach, though whether it was due to Dr. Sinclair's ominous tone or the continued presence of the contaminated plastic bag, he couldn't be sure. Medical cases that required magical intervention often involved complex fieldwork to identify and neutralize whatever supernatural influence was affecting the patients, which inevitably led to expectations that he would venture into whatever environment had caused the problem in the first place. The irony that his phobia might prevent him from helping genuinely ill people was not lost on him, and it added another layer of guilt to his already considerable professional anxieties.

"What sort of symptoms are we dealing with?" he asked, gesturing for her to take the chair opposite his consultation table while discretely sliding the plastic bag into a drawer where its unsettling presence would be less immediately obvious. "And you mentioned unusual circumstances—I assume you mean something beyond the typical medical history that might suggest supernatural involvement?"

Dr. Sinclair opened her medical bag and withdrew a small notebook filled with her precise handwriting, flipping through several pages before finding the entries that had brought her to his shop. Her expression was troubled in the way that suggested she was dealing with something that challenged her scientific worldview while simultaneously defying conventional explanation, a conflict that Hamish had seen in several medical professionals over the years when they first encountered genuinely magical phenomena.

"All three patients presented with severe disorientation, memory gaps, and what I can only describe as a form of selective amnesia that seems to center around specific geographical locations," she began, consulting her notes carefully. "The first was Mrs. Henderson from the post office, who went missing for six hours on Tuesday while walking her usual route to visit her sister in Kemnay. She was found by a search party sitting beside the road about a mile from where she'd started, with no memory of how she'd gotten there or what had happened during the missing time."

The details sent an uncomfortable chill down Hamish's spine that had nothing to do with the afternoon's unseasonable weather. Memory loss and disorientation were common side effects of certain types of magical interference, particularly spells designed to confuse or misdirect people who wandered into areas someone wanted to keep secret. Combined with the morning's account from the mysterious hiking woman, it suggested a pattern of magical activity that was affecting not just tourists but local residents as well, which significantly escalated the potential seriousness of the situation.

"The second case was young Jamie MacLeod—you know, the baker's son who helps with deliveries," Dr. Sinclair continued, her voice dropping slightly as if she were sharing confidential medical information rather than discussing supernatural phenomena in a magic shop. "He was driving the usual route to deliver bread to the rural properties north of town when he apparently became completely lost on roads he's traveled hundreds of times. His father found him parked at the side of the Alford road, staring straight ahead and completely unresponsive for nearly an hour before he seemed to 'wake up' with no recollection of stopping or of the previous three hours."

Hamish found himself thinking of the map the hiking woman had shown him, with its carefully marked locations where she'd encountered the strange arrangements of animated plastic bags. The Alford road ran directly through the area she'd identified as one of the more recent sites of magical disturbance, and the timing seemed to correlate with her account of increasingly powerful supernatural interference. The possibility that whatever rogue practitioner was responsible for the hiking incidents was also affecting local residents suggested either a serious escalation in their activities or a fundamental lack of control over the magical forces they were attempting to manipulate.

"And the third case?" he prompted, though he was beginning to suspect he already knew what Dr. Sinclair would tell him. The pattern was becoming disturbingly clear, and it pointed toward a magical crisis that would inevitably require direct investigation rather than the sort of remote consultation and treatment he preferred to offer.

The doctor's expression grew even more troubled as she turned to a fresh page in her notebook, and Hamish noticed that her usually steady handwriting showed signs of agitation in the hurried strokes and occasional crossed-out words. Whatever she was about to describe had clearly shaken her professional composure in ways that the previous cases had not, which did nothing to ease his growing sense of dread about the situation developing in the countryside around his normally quiet town.

"The third case is what really convinced me that we're dealing with something beyond conventional medical explanation," she said, her voice dropping to barely above a whisper despite the fact that they were alone in the shop. "Mrs. Aberdeen—your neighbor, actually—came to see me yesterday evening in a state of considerable distress. She'd gone to collect eggs from her chicken coop and found herself unable to remember how to get back to her own house, despite the fact that the coop is barely twenty yards from her kitchen door."

The mention of Mrs. Aberdeen and her chickens made Hamish's heart rate spike with an entirely different sort of anxiety than the supernatural concerns that had been troubling him all day. The thought of his neighbor wandering confused and lost in her own backyard, surrounded by what he knew to be a considerable population of cockerels and other poultry, created a perfect storm of professional obligation and personal terror that left him struggling to maintain his composure while Dr. Sinclair continued her account.

"She described feeling as though she were walking through thick fog, even though the evening was perfectly clear, and said that familiar landmarks kept shifting and changing when she wasn't looking directly at them," the doctor continued, apparently unaware of Hamish's internal crisis. "Most disturbing of all, she reported hearing voices calling her name from different directions, voices that sounded like deceased relatives trying to guide her home. She wandered her own property for over two hours before the disorientation suddenly lifted and she found herself standing exactly where she'd started, with her prize cockerel watching her as if nothing unusual had happened."

The image of Mrs. Aberdeen's prize cockerel—the very bird that had been terrorizing his garden that morning—standing witness to magical interference literally next door to his shop drove home the uncomfortable reality that whatever supernatural crisis was developing in the area had now reached his immediate vicinity. There would be no avoiding involvement or delegating the investigation to other practitioners when the effects were manifesting in his own backyard, regardless of how many of his personal phobias might be triggered in the process.

"All three cases show similar patterns of geographical disorientation and memory disruption, but what's particularly concerning is the escalating severity and the shrinking area of effect," Dr. Sinclair concluded, closing her notebook with a decisive snap. "Whatever is causing these incidents seems to be moving closer to populated areas and affecting people for longer periods of time. I'm genuinely worried that we might soon be dealing with cases where the memory loss or disorientation becomes permanent, or where someone gets lost in a truly dangerous location rather than just being confused in familiar surroundings."**Chapter 3**

That evening, Hamish found himself in the peculiar position of standing at his kitchen window with a pair of binoculars, ostensibly conducting surveillance of Mrs. Aberdeen's property while actually trying to work up the courage to venture into her backyard where the magical disturbances had allegedly occurred. The irony was not lost on him that his professional duty required him to investigate the very location where he knew Mrs. Aberdeen's prize cockerel held court, creating a perfect collision between his magical expertise and his most paralyzing fear. Through the lenses, he could see the chicken coop in question, a sturdy wooden structure painted cheerful yellow that seemed utterly innocuous in the fading daylight, though he knew that somewhere in its vicinity lurked the magnificent red terror that had destroyed his herb garden that morning.

The plastic bag from the hiking woman sat on his kitchen table, now contained within a circle of salt and surrounded by protective crystals that he'd arranged with considerable care after finally working up the nerve to handle the contaminated object directly. His preliminary examination had confirmed his worst suspicions about its nature—the bag had been deliberately enchanted with what appeared to be a confusion charm of considerable sophistication, though the magical signature was unlike anything in his extensive experience. Most practitioners developed distinctive patterns in their spellwork, like magical fingerprints that could be identified by those with sufficient training, but this working felt alien and unfamiliar in ways that suggested either a completely self-taught practitioner or someone trained in traditions very different from the Scottish Highland methods with which he was familiar.

A soft knock at his back door nearly made him drop the binoculars in surprise, and his heart began racing with the immediate assumption that Mrs. Aberdeen's cockerel had somehow learned to announce its presence before launching an attack. Through the glass panel, however, he could see the reassuring figure of Mrs. Aberdeen herself, wrapped in a thick woolen coat and carrying what appeared to be a covered casserole dish. Her expression was troubled in the way that suggested she'd come seeking his professional assistance rather than making a social call, though the presence of food indicated she was at least approaching the matter with characteristic Highland hospitality.

"Good evening, Mrs. Aberdeen," he said as he opened the door, carefully scanning the visible portions of her property for any sign of lurking poultry before stepping back to allow her entry. "Dr. Sinclair mentioned that you'd been having some unusual experiences recently. I hope you're feeling better this evening?"

The elderly woman settled herself at his kitchen table with the careful movements of someone who had lived through enough genuine hardships to take supernatural disturbances in stride, though he could see signs of strain around her eyes that suggested the previous evening's magical encounter had affected her more deeply than she was willing to admit. She uncovered the casserole dish to reveal what smelled like an excellent lamb stew, and he realized with a pang of guilt that he'd been so preoccupied with magical crises and cockerel anxiety that he'd completely forgotten to eat anything substantial since his morning cup of tea.

"Aye, I'm well enough now, though I'll admit yesterday evening gave me quite a turn," she said, ladling generous portions of stew into the bowls he provided while keeping her voice carefully matter-of-fact despite the supernatural nature of what she was discussing. "I've lived in that house for forty-three years, Hamish, and I know every inch of my property like the back of my hand. What happened out there wasn't natural confusion or an old woman's failing memory, whatever that young doctor might prefer to think about it."

Hamish accepted a bowl of the excellent-smelling stew while trying to process the implications of Mrs. Aberdeen's account and his own observations of the enchanted plastic bag. The fact that magical interference was occurring literally in his neighbor's backyard suggested that whatever rogue practitioner was responsible had either targeted the area around his shop specifically or was operating from somewhere very nearby. Neither possibility was particularly comforting, especially given that his own magical activities might have attracted unwanted attention from someone with unknown motives and questionable ethics regarding the use of supernatural forces.

"Dr. Sinclair mentioned that you experienced disorientation and heard voices calling your name," he said carefully, trying to balance his professional curiosity with appropriate sensitivity to what must have been a frightening experience for someone unaccustomed to magical phenomena. "Were you able to recognize any of the voices, or did they seem to be trying to lead you in any particular direction?"

Mrs. Aberdeen paused with her spoon halfway to her mouth, her expression growing distant as she apparently relived the previous evening's supernatural encounter. He could see her working through the memories with the methodical approach of someone accustomed to solving practical problems, though he suspected that no amount of Highland pragmatism could have prepared her for the reality of being caught in someone else's magical working.

"That's the strangest part of the whole business," she said finally, setting down her spoon and meeting his eyes with uncomfortable directness. "The voices were perfectly clear and sounded exactly like my late husband and my mother, both calling my name and telling me to come toward them. But they kept coming from different directions, sometimes simultaneously, as if multiple versions of the same people were scattered around my property trying to guide me to different locations."

The description sent a chill down Hamish's spine that had nothing to do with the evening's dropping temperature. Using the voices of deceased relatives to manipulate and confuse victims was a particularly unethical form of magical practice that crossed several serious moral boundaries. Most legitimate practitioners would consider such techniques a form of spiritual abuse, deliberately exploiting people's grief and emotional attachments for magical purposes. The fact that someone was apparently using such methods against innocent local residents suggested a level of callousness that made him genuinely angry despite his own fears about the investigation such activities would inevitably require.

"That's extremely disturbing," he said, unable to keep a note of outrage from his voice despite his efforts to maintain professional neutrality. "Using the voices of loved ones to manipulate people is considered one of the most serious ethical violations in magical practice. Whoever is responsible clearly has no regard for the psychological harm they might cause to their victims."

Mrs. Aberdeen nodded grimly, her own anger evident in the tight set of her jaw and the way her weathered hands clenched around her spoon. Despite her lack of magical training, she clearly understood that someone had deliberately violated her emotional boundaries in ways that went far beyond mere supernatural mischief or accidental magical interference.

"Aye, it felt like a cruel trick being played by someone who knew exactly how to hurt me most deeply," she said, her voice carrying decades of Highland steel beneath the gentle cadences of her accent. "What concerns me now is whether this... person... might try the same tactics on other folk in the area. There are plenty of widows and widowers in Inverurie who might be even more susceptible to hearing their departed spouses calling to them in the darkness."

The thought of other local residents being subjected to similar psychological manipulation made Hamish's stomach clench with a combination of professional obligation and personal dread. Whatever rogue practitioner was responsible would need to be identified and stopped before their activities caused serious psychological damage or put someone in genuine physical danger. The problem remained that conducting such an investigation would inevitably require him to venture into the countryside around Inverurie, where cockerels roamed freely and his debilitating phobia would make effective magical work nearly impossible.

"There's something else you should know," Mrs. Aberdeen continued, her voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper despite the fact that they were alone in his kitchen. "When the confusion finally lifted and I found myself back where I'd started, I noticed that someone had been in my chicken coop. Nothing was taken, and the birds weren't harmed, but I could tell that someone had been handling my eggs and moving things around inside the structure."

The mention of the chicken coop made Hamish's heart rate spike with familiar anxiety, though he tried to focus on the investigative implications rather than his phobia-induced panic. The fact that the magical disturbance had centered around Mrs. Aberdeen's poultry suggested either that the location held some specific significance for the practitioner responsible or that they were using the chickens themselves as part of their magical working. Some traditional practices did involve the use of barnyard animals for various spells, though legitimate practitioners would typically seek permission from the animals' owners rather than conducting clandestine operations under cover of confusion charms.

"Did you notice any other signs of disturbance around the coop or elsewhere on your property?" he asked, hoping his voice sounded steadier than he felt at the thought of having to examine the scene of magical interference that was located in prime cockerel territory. "Any unusual objects that might have been left behind, or changes to the area that seemed out of place?"

Mrs. Aberdeen reached into her coat pocket and withdrew something that made Hamish's blood run cold despite his growing familiarity with such objects over the course of the day. It was another plastic bag, similar in appearance to the one the hiking woman had left in his shop but somehow feeling even more saturated with unnatural magical energy. This one bore the logo of a local grocery chain and showed signs of recent handling, though the supernatural aura emanating from it was strong enough to make his magical senses recoil instinctively.

"I found this caught on the latch of the coop door this morning," she said, placing the bag on his kitchen table with obvious reluctance to handle it any longer than necessary. The morning mist clung to the cobblestone streets of Inverurie like a reluctant ghost, swirling around the ankles of early commuters who hurried past the unassuming shop nestled between MacLeod's bakery and the old pharmacy. Above the narrow doorway, a weathered sign creaked in the Highland breeze, its faded letters spelling out "Mystic Remedies & Curiosities." Most passersby assumed it sold herbal teas and crystal trinkets to tourists, which suited Hamish MacBride perfectly.

Behind the dusty window display of allegedly magical stones and dried herbs, Hamish was having what could charitably be called a morning crisis. The source of his distress strutted boldly across the small courtyard behind his shop—a magnificent red cockerel that belonged to Mrs. Aberdeen next door. The bird's proud chest puffed out as it surveyed its domain, completely unaware that it was causing a fully qualified wizard to cower behind his kitchen curtains.

"Blasted creature," Hamish muttered, his Scottish accent thick with irritation and embarrassment. At forty-three, he possessed considerable magical abilities that had taken decades to master, yet the sight of any cockerel reduced him to a quivering mess. The phobia had plagued him since childhood, when his grandmother's prize rooster had chased him up a tree and left him stranded there for hours. Even now, the memory of those beady eyes and that razor-sharp beak made his hands shake.

The cockerel let out a piercing crow, and Hamish actually jumped backward, knocking over a precariously balanced stack of ancient grimoires. As he scrambled to collect the scattered books, his mobile phone buzzed with an incoming call. The display showed "Moira Sinclair," and he answered with relief at the distraction.

"Hamish, thank goodness you're there," came the breathless voice of his oldest friend and fellow practitioner. Moira ran a similar establishment in Edinburgh, though hers catered to a more upscale clientele. "I've got some rather disturbing news from the Magical Practices Council."

Hamish settled into his worn armchair, keeping one eye on the window in case the cockerel decided to venture closer. "What sort of disturbing news? Please tell me they haven't decided to audit my licensing again."

"Worse, I'm afraid. There've been reports of magical interference in the Highlands. Environmental disturbances that suggest someone's been practicing without proper regard for consequences." Moira's voice dropped to a whisper. "They think there's a rogue practitioner operating somewhere in your area."

The news should have concerned Hamish more than it did, but he was distracted by the sound of scratching at his back door. Through the glass panel, he could see the cockerel pecking at something on his doorstep. His mouth went dry, and he had to clear his throat before responding.

"What sort of environmental disturbances?" he managed, though his voice came out slightly higher than intended.

"That's the odd bit. The reports mention unusual accumulations of non-biodegradable materials appearing in natural settings. Specifically, plastic bags. Hundreds of them, just materializing in forests and glens where they have no business being." Moira paused, and he could hear papers rustling. "The council thinks someone might be using them as focus objects for spells, which is not only environmentally irresponsible but potentially dangerous."

Hamish frowned, momentarily forgetting about his feathered nemesis. Using plastic bags as magical focuses was indeed unusual. Most practitioners preferred natural materials—crystals, wood, metals—substances that had formed over time and held earth's energy. Plastic was synthetic, mass-produced, and generally considered unsuitable for serious magical work.

"That does sound peculiar," he admitted. "Have there been any other effects reported?"

"Oh yes, that's where it gets really worrying. Several hikers have reported getting lost on familiar trails, and there've been complaints about compasses spinning wildly in certain areas. Classic signs of magical interference with natural energy patterns." Moira's tone grew more serious. "The council wants all licensed practitioners in the region to keep their eyes open and report anything suspicious."

A sudden loud crash from outside made Hamish leap to his feet, his heart hammering. Through the window, he could see that Mrs. Aberdeen's cockerel had somehow managed to knock over his small garden table, scattering the herbs he'd been drying there. The bird stood triumphant among the wreckage, fixing Hamish with what seemed like a deliberately challenging stare.

"Hamish? Are you still there?"

"Yes, sorry. Just having a small... domestic situation." He turned away from the window, trying to ignore the continued sounds of destruction from his garden. "I'll certainly keep watch for anything unusual. Though to be honest, Moira, I don't venture out into the countryside as much as I probably should."

This was a considerable understatement. Hamish's fear of cockerels meant he avoided most rural areas, where the creatures roamed freely. His practice focused primarily on indoor work—potion brewing, charm creation, and consultations with clients who came to his shop. It was a limitation that embarrassed him professionally, though he'd never admitted the real reason to anyone.

"Well, perhaps this will give you good cause to expand your horizons," Moira said cheerfully. "The council is organizing a regional meeting next week in Huntly. All practitioners are expected to attend."

Hamish's stomach clenched. Huntly was surrounded by farms, which meant cockerels. Lots of them. "I'm not sure I can make it, Moira. I've got several important clients coming in next week, and—"

"Hamish MacBride, don't you dare think about missing this meeting. The council takes attendance very seriously, especially when there's a potential rogue practitioner in the area." Her voice softened slightly. "Besides, it'll do you good to get out of that shop and socialize with other practitioners. You've become quite the hermit."

After ending the call, Hamish slumped back in his chair and contemplated his predicament. The cockerel had finally wandered away from his garden, leaving behind a scene of considerable destruction. He'd have to venture outside eventually to clean up the mess, but for now, he was content to remain safely indoors.

The shop's bell chimed softly as Hamish reluctantly made his way to the front, stepping carefully around the scattered grimoires he'd yet to properly reorganize. His first customer of the day stood examining a display of what appeared to be ordinary river stones, though each had been carefully selected for their natural magical properties. The woman was perhaps in her sixties, with silver hair pulled back in a practical bun and the weathered hands of someone who spent considerable time outdoors.

"Good morning," Hamish said, smoothing down his rumpled shirt and trying to project an air of professional competence despite his earlier encounter with Mrs. Aberdeen's cockerel. "I'm Hamish MacBride. Is there something particular you're looking for today?"

The woman turned, and he was struck by her unusually bright green eyes that seemed to assess him with uncomfortable intensity. She wore practical hiking boots and carried a well-used rucksack, suggesting she was indeed one of the tourists who occasionally wandered into his shop seeking Highland mysticism and locally-made trinkets.

"I'm hoping you might be able to help me with a rather unusual problem," she said, her accent marking her as English, probably from somewhere in the south. "I've been hiking in the area for the past week, and I've encountered some very strange occurrences that I'm told might require... specialized expertise."

Hamish felt a familiar flutter of anxiety in his chest. Clients seeking help with outdoor magical problems invariably expected him to venture into the countryside to investigate, which posed obvious difficulties given his phobia. He'd developed several polite ways to redirect such requests toward indoor consultations and remotely-prepared remedies, though he suspected his professional reputation suffered somewhat from his reluctance to do field work.

"I'd be happy to discuss whatever you've experienced," he said carefully, gesturing toward the small consultation area he'd arranged near the back of the shop. Two comfortable chairs faced each other across a low table where he typically laid out cards or examined objects clients brought for identification. "Perhaps you could start by describing what you've observed?"

The woman settled into the chair with obvious relief, setting her rucksack on the floor beside her. Up close, Hamish could see that despite her apparent fitness, she looked tired and somewhat shaken by whatever had brought her to his door. She reached into her jacket pocket and withdrew a crumpled plastic shopping bag, placing it on the table between them with the reverence usually reserved for dangerous artifacts.

"It started three days ago when I was walking the old drove road north of Alford," she began, her voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "I'd stopped for lunch in a lovely glen, completely pristine and remote, when I noticed something odd caught in the branches of a rowan tree. At first, I thought it was just litter blown in by the wind, but when I went to remove it, I found dozens more scattered throughout the area."

Hamish leaned forward, his interest genuinely piqued despite his growing concern about where this story might lead. The plastic bag on the table appeared ordinary enough—white with blue handles, the sort dispensed at any number of shops throughout Scotland. Yet something about it made his skin prickle with the familiar sensation that indicated magical residue.

"They weren't just randomly scattered, you see," the woman continued, watching his face carefully for his reaction. "They were arranged in patterns, almost like someone had deliberately placed them. And when I tried to collect them for proper disposal, the strangest thing happened. My compass began spinning wildly, and I became completely disoriented despite having walked that same path many times before."

The details matched perfectly with what Moira had told him about the reports reaching the Magical Practices Council. Hamish reached out tentatively toward the bag on the table, stopping just short of actually touching it. Even at a distance of several inches, he could feel the peculiar energy emanating from the seemingly mundane object. It wasn't the clean, natural power he was accustomed to working with, but something artificial and unsettling that made his magical senses recoil instinctively.

"Did you experience any other unusual effects?" he asked, pulling his hand back and folding his arms across his chest. "Changes in temperature, strange sounds, or perhaps the sensation of being watched?"

The woman nodded eagerly, clearly relieved to have found someone who took her account seriously rather than dismissing it as imagination or tourist nerves. "All of those things, actually. The area became unnaturally cold despite the sunny weather, and I kept hearing what sounded like whispering voices carried on the wind. But the most disturbing part was the feeling that something was deliberately trying to confuse me, to keep me wandering in circles."

Hamish's mind raced through the possibilities, none of them particularly pleasant. Magical practitioners occasionally used misdirection spells to protect sensitive locations or discourage unwanted visitors, but such workings typically employed natural focuses and were designed to guide people gently away rather than trap them in confusion. The use of plastic bags suggested someone with either very unconventional training or a deliberate disregard for proper magical principles.

"I managed to break free of whatever influence was affecting me," the woman continued, "but only after I'd been walking in circles for nearly three hours. When I finally found my way back to the main path, I looked back toward the glen and saw the most extraordinary sight. The plastic bags were moving despite there being no wind, fluttering and dancing as if they were alive."

Hamish sat back in his chair, processing the woman's account with growing unease. The description of animated plastic bags defied several fundamental principles of magical practice that he'd learned during his formal training. Inanimate objects could certainly be enchanted to move or perform specific functions, but such spells required considerable skill and energy to maintain. More troubling was the apparent malevolent intent behind the working—deliberately disorienting hikers suggested someone using magic for harmful purposes, which violated the most basic ethical guidelines governing legitimate practitioners.

"I'm afraid what you've described sounds quite serious indeed," he said finally, trying to keep his voice steady despite the implications racing through his mind. "The good news is that you managed to escape whatever influence was affecting you, which suggests the magic involved isn't overwhelmingly powerful. The concerning part is that someone appears to be using enchanted objects to trap or confuse people in remote locations, which could pose genuine danger to other hikers."

The woman reached into her rucksack and withdrew a folded Ordnance Survey map, spreading it across the table with practiced efficiency. Her finger traced a route marked in red ink, following what Hamish recognized as one of the more remote hiking paths that wound through the hills north of his location. She'd marked several spots with small X's, and he noticed with growing alarm that they were scattered across a fairly wide area rather than concentrated in a single location.

"I've encountered these strange arrangements in three different locations over the past week," she explained, pointing to each marked spot in turn. "The first was near Corgarff Castle, the second along the Lecht Road, and the most recent in the glen I mentioned near Alford. Each time, the effect seemed stronger, as if whoever is responsible is either gaining confidence or increasing their magical output."

Hamish studied the map with growing dread, not because of the magical implications—though those were certainly serious enough—but because he recognized all three locations as areas where Mrs. Aberdeen's cockerel and its numerous countryside cousins would be roaming freely. The thought of venturing into such territory to investigate magical disturbances made his palms sweat and his heart rate accelerate in ways that had nothing to do with the potential dangers posed by rogue practitioners.

"Have you reported these incidents to the local authorities?" he asked, though he already suspected what the answer would be. The police were generally ill-equipped to handle magical disturbances, and most officers would likely dismiss such reports as the product of overactive imaginations or tourist unfamiliarity with Highland terrain.

The woman shook her head with obvious frustration. "I tried speaking to the constable in Huntly, but he seemed to think I'd simply gotten turned around due to inexperience, despite my explaining that I've been hiking these hills for over fifteen years. He did mention that there had been several other reports of hikers becoming lost in areas where they'd never had difficulty before, but he attributed it to unusually foggy weather patterns rather than anything supernatural."

This matched the pattern Moira had described, confirming that the situation was indeed serious enough to warrant the Magical Practices Council's attention. Hamish found himself in the uncomfortable position of being perhaps the only qualified practitioner in the immediate area who could investigate these incidents, while simultaneously being the least capable of actually doing so due to his debilitating phobia. The irony of his situation would have been amusing if it weren't so potentially dangerous for the hiking public.

"I think your instincts in seeking out specialized help were absolutely correct," he said, carefully refolding the map and handing it back to her. "What you've described definitely sounds like magical interference, and not the benign sort that legitimate practitioners might use to protect sensitive natural areas. The deliberate confusion and disorientation suggest someone with either malicious intent or a serious lack of understanding about the consequences of their actions."

The woman leaned forward intently, her green eyes brightening with what appeared to be relief at finally having her experiences taken seriously by someone with relevant expertise. "Does this mean you'll be able to help? I realize it might seem like a small matter compared to more dramatic magical emergencies, but I'm genuinely concerned about other hikers who might not be as fortunate as I was in finding their way out of those enchanted areas."

Hamish felt his throat tighten as he struggled to find a response that wouldn't reveal his shameful limitations while still offering some form of assistance. He could hardly explain that his fear of cockerels made fieldwork essentially impossible, nor could he simply refuse to help when someone's safety might be at stake. The professional reputation he'd spent years building would suffer considerably if word spread that he was unwilling to investigate legitimate magical disturbances in his own territory.

"I'll certainly need to look into this matter further," he said carefully, buying himself time to think of alternatives to personal field investigation. "However, I should mention that this situation may be part of a larger pattern that the regional magical authorities are already aware of. There's to be a meeting of practitioners next week where these incidents will undoubtedly be discussed and coordinated responses planned."

The mention of the upcoming meeting reminded him uncomfortably of his own reluctance to attend, and he realized that his professional obligations were rapidly becoming impossible to avoid. Whether he liked it or not, his expertise would be expected and required in dealing with whatever rogue practitioner was causing these disturbances. The thought of having to venture into cockerel-populated countryside while simultaneously tracking down potentially dangerous magical workings made him feel slightly nauseated.

"In the meantime," he continued, hoping his voice sounded more confident than he felt, "I'd strongly recommend that you avoid hiking alone in remote areas, particularly the locations you've already identified as problematic. If you do encounter any more unusual phenomena, please contact me immediately rather than trying to investigate further on your own."

The woman nodded seriously, gathering her belongings with the efficient movements of someone accustomed to outdoor adventures. She paused at the door, however, turning back with an expression that struck Hamish as oddly calculating for someone who had supposedly come seeking help with a frightening supernatural experience.

"I do hope you'll be able to resolve this situation quickly," she said, her tone carrying subtle undertones that made him suddenly uncomfortable. "It would be such a shame if these beautiful Highland paths became unsafe for visitors due to some practitioner's carelessness or malice. I'm sure someone with your obvious expertise will have no trouble tracking down whoever is responsible."

After she left, Hamish stood at his shop window watching her disappear down the cobblestone street with a growing sense that their conversation had contained layers of meaning he'd failed to fully grasp. Something about her manner in those final moments had shifted from grateful tourist to something more calculated and assessing, though he couldn't quite put his finger on what had triggered his unease. Perhaps it was simply his own guilt over his limitations coloring his perception of her perfectly reasonable expectations for professional assistance.

**Chapter 2**

The afternoon brought an unseasonable chill that seemed to seep through the very stones of Inverurie, and Hamish found himself pacing restlessly around his shop while trying to make sense of the morning's unsettling encounter. The plastic bag the hiking woman had left behind sat on his consultation table like an accusation, its ordinary appearance belying the distinctly unnatural energy that continued to emanate from it in waves that made his skin crawl. Every few minutes, he would approach it with the intention of conducting a proper magical analysis, only to retreat again when the artificial wrongness of its aura became too overwhelming to bear. He had dealt with cursed objects before, items imbued with malevolent intent or corrupted by dark practices, but this felt different—not evil exactly, but fundamentally alien to the natural order of things in a way that defied his decades of experience.

The shop's bell chimed again just as he was contemplating whether to contact Moira for advice on handling the contaminated bag, and he looked up to see a familiar figure entering with the careful movements of someone trying not to disturb anything important. Dr. Margaret Sinclair—no relation to his Edinburgh colleague despite the shared surname—served as the local GP and had developed something of a reputation for referring patients with inexplicable ailments to Hamish's more unconventional practice. She was a practical woman in her fifties who had initially approached his services with considerable skepticism, only to become one of his most reliable sources of referrals after he'd successfully treated several cases that conventional medicine had failed to resolve.

"Good afternoon, Hamish," she said, settling her medical bag carefully beside one of his display cases filled with what appeared to tourists to be decorative crystals but were actually precisely calibrated healing stones. "I'm hoping you might have some insight into a rather puzzling situation that's developed over the past few days. I've had three separate patients present with symptoms that don't fit any conventional diagnosis, and they all share some rather unusual circumstances that I think might be relevant to your area of expertise."

Hamish felt a familiar sinking sensation in his stomach, though whether it was due to Dr. Sinclair's ominous tone or the continued presence of the contaminated plastic bag, he couldn't be sure. Medical cases that required magical intervention often involved complex fieldwork to identify and neutralize whatever supernatural influence was affecting the patients, which inevitably led to expectations that he would venture into whatever environment had caused the problem in the first place. The irony that his phobia might prevent him from helping genuinely ill people was not lost on him, and it added another layer of guilt to his already considerable professional anxieties.

"What sort of symptoms are we dealing with?" he asked, gesturing for her to take the chair opposite his consultation table while discretely sliding the plastic bag into a drawer where its unsettling presence would be less immediately obvious. "And you mentioned unusual circumstances—I assume you mean something beyond the typical medical history that might suggest supernatural involvement?"

Dr. Sinclair opened her medical bag and withdrew a small notebook filled with her precise handwriting, flipping through several pages before finding the entries that had brought her to his shop. Her expression was troubled in the way that suggested she was dealing with something that challenged her scientific worldview while simultaneously defying conventional explanation, a conflict that Hamish had seen in several medical professionals over the years when they first encountered genuinely magical phenomena.

"All three patients presented with severe disorientation, memory gaps, and what I can only describe as a form of selective amnesia that seems to center around specific geographical locations," she began, consulting her notes carefully. "The first was Mrs. Henderson from the post office, who went missing for six hours on Tuesday while walking her usual route to visit her sister in Kemnay. She was found by a search party sitting beside the road about a mile from where she'd started, with no memory of how she'd gotten there or what had happened during the missing time."

The details sent an uncomfortable chill down Hamish's spine that had nothing to do with the afternoon's unseasonable weather. Memory loss and disorientation were common side effects of certain types of magical interference, particularly spells designed to confuse or misdirect people who wandered into areas someone wanted to keep secret. Combined with the morning's account from the mysterious hiking woman, it suggested a pattern of magical activity that was affecting not just tourists but local residents as well, which significantly escalated the potential seriousness of the situation.

"The second case was young Jamie MacLeod—you know, the baker's son who helps with deliveries," Dr. Sinclair continued, her voice dropping slightly as if she were sharing confidential medical information rather than discussing supernatural phenomena in a magic shop. "He was driving the usual route to deliver bread to the rural properties north of town when he apparently became completely lost on roads he's traveled hundreds of times. His father found him parked at the side of the Alford road, staring straight ahead and completely unresponsive for nearly an hour before he seemed to 'wake up' with no recollection of stopping or of the previous three hours."

Hamish found himself thinking of the map the hiking woman had shown him, with its carefully marked locations where she'd encountered the strange arrangements of animated plastic bags. The Alford road ran directly through the area she'd identified as one of the more recent sites of magical disturbance, and the timing seemed to correlate with her account of increasingly powerful supernatural interference. The possibility that whatever rogue practitioner was responsible for the hiking incidents was also affecting local residents suggested either a serious escalation in their activities or a fundamental lack of control over the magical forces they were attempting to manipulate.

"And the third case?" he prompted, though he was beginning to suspect he already knew what Dr. Sinclair would tell him. The pattern was becoming disturbingly clear, and it pointed toward a magical crisis that would inevitably require direct investigation rather than the sort of remote consultation and treatment he preferred to offer.

The doctor's expression grew even more troubled as she turned to a fresh page in her notebook, and Hamish noticed that her usually steady handwriting showed signs of agitation in the hurried strokes and occasional crossed-out words. Whatever she was about to describe had clearly shaken her professional composure in ways that the previous cases had not, which did nothing to ease his growing sense of dread about the situation developing in the countryside around his normally quiet town.

"The third case is what really convinced me that we're dealing with something beyond conventional medical explanation," she said, her voice dropping to barely above a whisper despite the fact that they were alone in the shop. "Mrs. Aberdeen—your neighbor, actually—came to see me yesterday evening in a state of considerable distress. She'd gone to collect eggs from her chicken coop and found herself unable to remember how to get back to her own house, despite the fact that the coop is barely twenty yards from her kitchen door."

The mention of Mrs. Aberdeen and her chickens made Hamish's heart rate spike with an entirely different sort of anxiety than the supernatural concerns that had been troubling him all day. The thought of his neighbor wandering confused and lost in her own backyard, surrounded by what he knew to be a considerable population of cockerels and other poultry, created a perfect storm of professional obligation and personal terror that left him struggling to maintain his composure while Dr. Sinclair continued her account.

"She described feeling as though she were walking through thick fog, even though the evening was perfectly clear, and said that familiar landmarks kept shifting and changing when she wasn't looking directly at them," the doctor continued, apparently unaware of Hamish's internal crisis.
